In 2017, it was revealed that the wedding was paid for by funds, laundered through Dubai, and granted to a Gupta-linked company by the [[Free State Province]] government, purportedly as part of the [[Vrede Dairy Project]].{{cite web |url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/guptaleaks-the-dubai-laundromat-how-millions-milked-from-free-state-government-paid-for-sun-city-wedding-20170629 |title=#GuptaLeaks: The Dubai Laundromat – How millions milked from Free State government paid for Sun City wedding |date=30 June 2017 |website=[[News24]] |access-date=19 February 2018}}] In January 2018, the Asset Forfeiture Unit of the [[National Prosecuting Authority]] seized R220 million that Free State Department of Agriculture under [[Mosebenzi Zwane]] had paid to the Gupta family as part of this project, calling it a "scheme designed to defraud and steal monies from the department".{{cite web|url=https://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/breaking-npa-freezes-r220m-land-linked-to-gupta-farm-20180120|title=NPA freezes R220m, land linked to Gupta farm|date=20 January 2018}} The [[Hawks (South Africa)|Hawks]] unit of South Africa's Directorate for Priority Crime Investigation (DPCI) raided the offices of [[Ace Magashule]], the Premier of the Free State, in connection with the project.{{cite news|url=http://ewn.co.za/2018/01/26/hawks-raid-fs-premier-s-office-over-gupta-linked-vrede-dairy|title=Hawks Raid FS Premier's Office Over Gupta-linked Vrede Dairy Farm|first=Barry|last=Bateman|date=25 January 2018}} ===Influence over Cabinet appointments=== In 2016, a series of allegations of the Guptas' influence over appointments to the South African Cabinet came to the fore. Former ANC MP Vytjie Mentor claimed that in 2010 the Guptas had offered her the position of Minister of Public Enterprises, provided that she arranged for [[South African Airways]] to drop their India route, allowing a Gupta linked company (Jet Airways) to take on the route.{{cite news|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2016/03/18/Zuma-said-its-OK-Ntombazana-says-former-ANC-MP-Vytjie-Mentor|title='Zuma said it's OK Ntombazana,' says former ANC MP Vytjie Mentor|publisher=Times Live|date=18 March 2016}} She said she declined the offer, which occurred at the Guptas' Saxonwold residence, while President Zuma was in another room. This came a few days before a cabinet reshuffle in which minister [[Barbara Hogan]] was dismissed by Zuma. The Gupta family denied that the meeting took place and denied offering Vytijie a ministerial position.{{cite news |last=Khoza |first=Amanda |date=15 March 2016 |title=Gupta family denies offering former ANC MP top job |url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/gupta-family-denies-offering-former-anc-mp-top-job-20160315 |newspaper=news24 |location= |access-date=24 June 2016}} President Zuma claimed that he had no recollection of Vytjie Mentor.{{cite news |last1=Khoza |first1=Amanda |last2=Tandwa |first2=Lizeka |date=15 March 2016 |title=Zuma has 'no recollection' of Mentor - Presidency |url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/zuma-has-no-recollection-of-mentor-presidency-20160315 |newspaper=news24 |location= |access-date=24 June 2016}} Deputy Finance Minister [[Mcebisi Jonas]] confirmed media reports that he had been offered the ministerial position by the Guptas shortly before the disastrous dismissal of Finance Minister [[Nhlanhla Nene]] in December 2015, but had rejected the offer out of hand as "it makes a mockery of our hard-earned democracy‚ the trust of our people and no one apart from the President of the Republic appoints ministers".{{cite news|url=http://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/2016/03/16/full-statement-by-deputy-finance-minister-mcebisi-jonas-on-gupta-job-offer|title=Full statement by Deputy Finance Minister Mcebisi Jonas on Gupta job offer|date=16 March 2016|publisher=The Sowetan}} The Gupta family denied offering Jonas the job of Finance Minister.{{cite news |author= |title=Gupta family denies offering Jonas South Africa's finance minister role |url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFKCN0WI2J7 |newspaper=Reuters |location= |date=16 March 2016 |access-date=24 June 2016}} The [[Sunday Times (South Africa)|Sunday Times]] has reported that the Minister of Mineral Resources, Mosebenzi Zwane, and then Minister of Co-operative Governance and Traditional Affairs, [[David van Rooyen]] (who was controversially appointed by President Zuma as Minister of Finance in December 2015) met with members of the Gupta family in [[Dubai]]. Van Rooyen allegedly met with them only a few days after his unsuccessful appointment to be Minister of Finance on the 20 December 2015. Minister Zwane assisted in the sale of a large coal mine to a Gupta owned company.{{cite web | url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/stnews/2016/04/10/Gupta-ministers-in-secret-trips-to-Dubai1 | title='Gupta ministers' in secret trips to Dubai | publisher=Sunday Times | date=10 April 2016 | accessdate=10 April 2016 |author1=Jika, Thanduxolo |author2=Hunter, Qaanitah}} Former bodyguards of the Gupta family have stated that they often saw important government officials, such as [[Hlaudi Motsoeneng]] the COO of the state broadcaster the [[South African Broadcasting Corporation|SABC]], and large amounts of money in cash moving out of the Gupta's Saxonwold estate. The bodyguards also stated that Ajay Gupta would visit President Zuma up to three times a week until 2015 at the presidential guest house in Pretoria. A spokesperson for president Zuma denies that the visits ever happened.{{Cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-04-28-what-the-gupta-guards-saw|title=What the Gupta guards saw: VIPs and bags of cash|last=Bezuidenhout|first=Jessica|website=The M&G Online|access-date=2016-05-07}} Ranjeni Munusamy of the [[Daily Maverick]] has stated the "Gupta family has effectively usurped the function of the ANC deployment committee"{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-03-17-zupta-chamber-of-secrets-blown-open-tide-turns-in-anc | title=Zupta chamber of secrets blown open: Tide turns in ANC | publisher=[[Daily Maverick]] | date=17 March 2016 | accessdate=19 March 2016 | author=Munusamy, Ranjeni}} thereby undermining the party's ability to independently and legitimately select senior ministers and executives in government and state owned companies. The Gupta's alleged influence was the subject of an investigation into "state capture" by outgoing [[Public Protector (South Africa)|Public Protector]] [[Thuli Madonsela]]. President Zuma and Minister Des van Rooyen applied for an interdict to prevent the publication of the report on 14 October 2016, Madonsela's last day in office.{{cite news|url=https://www.enca.com/south-africa/zuma-interdicts-madonselas-state-capture-report|title=Zuma halts Madonsela's state capture report|date=13 October 2016|publisher=eNCA}} Van Rooyen's application was dismissed, and the President withdrew his application, leading to the release of the report on 2 November. The report recommends the establishment of a judicial commission of enquiry into the issues identified.{{cite news|url=http://ewn.co.za/2016/11/03/madonsela-broadens-investigating-scope-of-future-judicial-commission-of-inquiry|title=State Capture Report: What Madonsela Wants Inquiry to Probe|publisher=EWN|date=3 November 2016}} The report recommends that a full probe of Mr. Zuma's dealings with the Guptas should be conducted by a commission of inquiry, with the findings published within 180 days. Zuma and Des van Rooyen have since denied any wrongdoing.{{cite news |last1=Parkinson |first1=Joe |last2=Steinhauser |first2=Gabriele |date=6 November 2016 |title=South Africa report cites ‘worrying’ signs of government corruption |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/thousands-join-antigovernment-protests-in-south-africa-1478079209 |newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]] |location= |access-date=1 December 2016}} The Gupta's lawyer disputed the evidence in the report.{{Cite news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/business/news/statecapture-report-molefe-gupta-ties-revealed-2086410|title=#StateCapture report: Molefe-Gupta ties revealed |website=IOL news |access-date=2016-12-25}} The Gupta family have denied any wrongdoing and welcomed the opportunity to challenge the report’s findings in an official judiciary inquiry.{{cite news |last=Macharia |first=James |date=3 Nov 2016 |title=South Africa's Guptas to challenge state capture report at inquiry |url=http://www.cnbcafrica.com/news/southern-africa/2016/11/03/south-africas-guptas-to-challenge-influence-peddling-report-at-inquiry/ |newspaper=CNBC Africa |location= |access-date=1 December 2016}}{{Cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-10-17-gupta-bombshell-zuma-on-the-ropes-after-gordhans-gloves-come-off|title=Gupta bombshell: Zuma on the ropes after Gordhan's gloves come off|last=Dzonzi|first=Mike Cohen, Thembisile Augustine|newspaper=The M&G Online|access-date=2016-12-25}} On 25 November 2016, Zuma announced that the Presidency would be reviewing the contents of the state capture report.{{Cite news|url=http://city-press.news24.com/News/zuma-to-take-state-capture-report-on-review-20161125|title=Zuma to take state capture report on review|newspaper=CityPress|access-date=2016-12-08}} He said it "was done in a funny way" with "no fairness at all" and argued he was not given enough time to respond to the public protector.{{Cite news|url=http://citizen.co.za/news/news-national/1357691/zuma-take-madonselas-state-capture-report-review/|title=Zuma to launch a review on Madonsela's state capture report|last=Williams|first=Denise|newspaper=The Citizen|access-date=2016-12-08}} In late May 2017 a number of emails were leaked to the public from the Guptas and their associates implicating them in efforts to appoint government ministers and heads of government owned companies in addition to coordinating activities with political figures associated with President Zuma for their own personal gain. Most notable were efforts to appoint Gupta friendly executives for [[Transnet]], [[Eskom]], the appointment of Mosebenzi Zwane as [[Minister of Mineral Resources (South Africa)|minister of mineral resources]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/stnews/2017/05/28/Here-they-are-The-emails-that-prove-the-Guptas-run-South-Africa|title=Here they are: The emails that prove the Guptas run South Africa|last=Staff Reporter|first=|date=2017-05-28|website=Sunday Times|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170528133921/http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/stnews/2017/05/28/Here-they-are-The-emails-that-prove-the-Guptas-run-South-Africa|archive-date=2017-05-28|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-06-07}}{{Cite news|url=https://businesstech.co.za/news/government/178067/this-is-the-action-that-must-be-taken-on-gupta-emails-legal-expert/|title=This is the action that must be taken on Gupta emails – legal expert|last=|first=|date=7 June 2017|work=Business Tech|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en-ZA}} The [[African National Congress Youth League|ANC Youth League]] and the pro-Gupta{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-05-16-black-first-land-first-the-black-agenda-is-upon-us/|title=Black First Land First: The Black Agenda is upon us {{!}} Daily Maverick|last=Simelane|first=Bheki|date=16 May 2016|website=www.dailymaverick.co.za|language=en|access-date=2017-06-07}} political party [[Black First Land First]] (BLF) disputed the authenticity of the emails whilst the Communist Party of South Africa stated that the emails "look genuine".{{Cite news|url=http://citizen.co.za/news/news-national/1532929/gupta-e-mails-genuine-sacp/|title=Gupta emails ‘genuine’ – SACP|last=|first=|date=|work=The Citizen|access-date=2017-06-07|language=en}} In January 2018, Ramaphosa announced that there would indeed be a [[Commission of Inquiry into State Capture]]https://www.sastatecapture.org.za/site/about/mandate, and this would be chaired by [[Deputy Chief Justice of South Africa]] [[Raymond Zondo]]. Hearings began on 20th August, 2018https://www.corruptionwatch.org.za/state-capture-commission-almost-running/, and are expected to last for two years. ===Mining and energy interests=== Oakbay Resources & Energy is a mining and processing company run by the Gupta family.{{cite web |url=http://quotes.wsj.com/ZA/XJSE/ORL/company-people |title=Oakbay Resources & Energy Ltd |author= |date= |website=Wall Street Journal |publisher= |access-date=18 February 2016}} It supplies minerals and mineral products, such as gold, uranium, platinum, coal and diamonds and also conducts trackless/mechanised mining, track bound mining, breast mining, down-dip mining and open-pit gold operation. Oakbay Resources & Energy began trading on the JSE on 28 November 2014.{{cite news |last=Crowley |first=Kevin |date=1 December 2014 |title=Oakbay’s value close to top mining firm |url=http://www.iol.co.za/business/news/oakbays-value-close-to-top-mining-firm-1788584 |newspaper=Independent Online |location= |access-date=18 February 2015}} ====Iron ore dispute==== In 2010 the Gupta owned firm Imperial Crown Trading (ICT), along with Duduzane Zuma who was a part owner in ICT, were involved in a dispute with [[ArcelorMittal]] and [[Anglo American plc]] over the rightful ownership of [[Kumba Iron Ore]], which owns [[Sishen mine]], one of Africa's largest iron mines. The Department of Mineral Resources granted the ICT 21.4% ownership in the mine when ArcelorMittal did not renew their mining licence in time. The case was taken to the [[Constitutional Court of South Africa|Constitutional Court]] where, in 2013, it was ruled that the Gupta/Zuma consortium could not claim rightful ownership. Had they won the case ArcelorMittal would have had to pay them R800 million (US$80 million).{{cite web | url=http://www.biznews.com/interviews/2013/12/12/huge-relief-as-constitutional-court-rules-for-kumba-sends-gupta-owned-ict-packing/ | title="Huge relief" as Constitutional Court rules for Kumba, sends Gupta-owned ICT packing – victory for SA’s independent judiciary | publisher=Biznews | date=12 December 2013 | accessdate=13 February 2016 |author1=Brigid Taylor |author2=Alec Hogg }} ====Coal==== {{See also | Eskom#Corruption_scandal}} The South African [[Sunday Times (South Africa)|Sunday Times]] alleged that a Gupta owned company, Tegeta, benefited from official connections in the awarding of a R4 billion contract to supply coal to the state electrical utility company [[Eskom]].{{cite web | url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/stnews/2015/09/13/How-Eskom-bowed-to-Guptas | title=How Eskom bowed to Guptas | publisher=Sunday Times | date=13 September 2015 | accessdate=9 February 2016 | author=Skiti, Sabelo}} The Mines Minister Mosebenzi Zwane denied this allegation saying that he didn’t give Tegeta any preferential treatment and was only interested in preserving jobs following Tegeta’s purchase of a coal mine that supplies Eskom.{{cite news |last1=Burkhardt |first1=Paul |last2=Wild |first2=Franz |last3=Cohen |first3=Michael |date=12 February 2016 |title=Gupta-Zuma Coal Deal Cleared With Vow to Keep South African Jobs|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-02-12/gupta-zuma-coal-deal-cleared-with-vow-to-keep-south-african-jobs |newspaper=Bloomberg |location= |access-date=18 February 2016}} According to the business rescue practitioners Tegeta will also take on the R2.4 billion penalty imposed by Eskom on Optimum for delivering poor-quality coal.{{cite news |last=Comrie |first=Susan |date=13 December 2015 |title=Guptas’ R2.15bn deal for Eskom coal contracts |url=http://city-press.news24.com/Business/guptas-r215bn-deal-for-eskom-coal-contracts-20151211 |newspaper=City Press |location= |access-date=18 February 2016}} On the 12th June, City Press alleged that Eskom awarded Tegeta a contract worth more than R564 million, paying in advance in order to ‘bail out the Guptas’ and that it also allowed the company to divert a significant portion of Optimum’s coal to another power station in order to be bought at a higher price.{{cite news |last= Comrie |first= Susan |date=12 June 2016 |title= How Eskom bailed out the Guptas|url= http://city-press.news24.com/News/how-eskom-bailed-out-the-guptas-20160612 |newspaper=City Press |location= |access-date=24 June 2016}} An executive for Eskom said that paying companies in advance has been done before and that Eskom was not diverting coal from the Hendrina power plant to the Arnot power plant.{{cite news |last1= Burkhardt |first1=Paul |last2=Crowley |first2=Kevin |date=13 June 2016 |title=Eskom Prepaid Guptas’ Tegeta $38 Million for Coal Supplies |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-06-13/eskom-paid-guptas-tegeta-in-advance-for-coal-to-ensure-supplies |newspaper=Bloomberg |location= |access-date=24 June 2016}} Nazeem Howa described allegations as “sublime and ridiculous” and that prepayments were a standard practice of Eskom.{{cite news |author= |title=Allegations against Oakbay and Guptas a conspiracy, says Nazeem Howa |url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/business/energy/2016/06/13/allegations-against-oakbay-and-guptas-a-conspiracy-says-nazeem-howa |newspaper=Business Day |location= |date=13 June 2016 |access-date=24 June 2016}} On 8 September 2016, Nazeem Howa told Bloomberg that Oakbay Investments had signed a contract to export power-plant coal at a premium to the highest price it gets from Eskom of R150 ($11) per ton. He declined to comment on whether its export allocation was being sold.{{cite news |last=Burkhardt |first=Paul |date=8 September 2016 |title=Guptas’ Oakbay signs coal-export deal at premium to Eskom |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-09-08/guptas-oakbay-signs-coal-export-deal-at-premium-to-eskom-prices |newspaper=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |location= |access-date=4 October 2016}} ====Uranium interests, Nhlanhla Nene, Pravin Gordhan and KPMG==== {{see also| Jacob Zuma#Dismissal of Nhlanhla Nene|KPMG#2017 South African corruption scandal}} The family is alleged by the [[Rand Daily Mail]] to have worked closely with Zuma to secure interests in South Africa's nuclear energy sector. In 2014 the South African government announced that a 9 600 MW nuclear procurement programme that entailed the construction of six to eight nuclear reactors at an estimated cost of between R800 billion to R1.6 trillion (US$50-billion to US$100 billion) was under consideration. This proposal was approved by the Zuma cabinet on the 9 December 2015. Zuma's [[Jacob Zuma#Dismissal of Nhlanhla Nene|controversial dismissal]] of then minister of finance [[Nhlanhla Nene]] on the 9 December 2015 is alleged to have been partially motivated by Nene's department's resistance to the nuclear agreement. President Zuma stated that this move was motivated by Nene's nomination to head the African Regional Centre of the New Development Bank/Brics Bank.{{cite news |last=Singh |first=Kaveel |date=12 December 2015 |title=Zuma explains Nhlanhla Nene’s removal |url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/2015/12/12/zuma-explains-nhlanhla-nenes-removal |newspaper=Business Day Live |location= |access-date=18 February 2016}} Zuma's statement was met with skepticism by the media and opposition political parties, partly because Nene was unaware of his nomination to the post.{{cite web | url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/2016/01/12/nene-merely-a-nominee-for-brics-bank-africa-position | title=Nene merely a nominee for Brics bank Africa position | publisher=Business Day | date=12 January 2016 | accessdate=26 February 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/2a49965e-a281-11e5-8d70-42b68cfae6e4.html#axzz41Gb1Aylz | title=South Africa’s Zuma counts cost of fiasco over finance minister | publisher=Financial Times | date=14 December 2016 | accessdate=26 February 2016 | author=Andrew England | subscription=yes}}{{cite web | url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/maimane-slams-zuma-over-nene-brics-move-20151211 | title=Maimane slams Zuma over Nene Brics move | publisher=News24 | date=11 December 2015 | accessdate=26 February 2016 | author=Kaveel Singh}}{{cite web | url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/four-possible-reasons-why-nene-was-fired-20151210 | title=Four possible reasons why Nene was fired | publisher=[[News24]] | date=10 December 2015 | accessdate=2 January 2016 | author=Areff, Ahmed}}{{cite web | url=http://businesstech.co.za/news/government/106705/why-zuma-sacked-nene-according-to-the-eff-and-da/ | title=Why Zuma sacked Nene according to the EFF and DA | publisher=Businesstech.co.za | date=9 December 2015 | accessdate=5 January 2016}} Nene was briefly replaced with the little known [[David van Rooyen]] before public criticism, and a sharp decline in the currency, and the stock market lead to Zuma re-appointing former minister of finance [[Pravin Gordhan]] to the position instead. Strong links between both of Van Rooyen's top two advisers and the Gupta family came to light a few months after Nene's dismissal.{{cite web | url=http://www.biznews.com/leadership/2016/02/15/named-van-rooyens-two-gupta-advisors-who-almost-hijacked-sa-treasury/ | title=Named: Van Rooyen’s two Gupta "advisors" who almost hijacked SA Treasury | publisher=Biznews | date=15 February 2016 | accessdate=26 February 2016 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301014609/http://www.biznews.com/leadership/2016/02/15/named-van-rooyens-two-gupta-advisors-who-almost-hijacked-sa-treasury/ | archivedate=1 March 2016 | df= }}{{cite web | url=http://www.biznews.com/leadership/2016/02/15/named-van-rooyens-two-gupta-advisors-who-almost-hijacked-sa-treasury/ | title=Floyd Shivambu: Here’s why Zuma fired Nene, deployed backbencher Van Rooyen | publisher=Biznews | date=21 December 2015 | accessdate=26 February 2016 | author=Shivambu, Floyd | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301014609/http://www.biznews.com/leadership/2016/02/15/named-van-rooyens-two-gupta-advisors-who-almost-hijacked-sa-treasury/ | archivedate=1 March 2016 | df= }} Shortly after Gordhan's appointment an investigation was initiated by the Hawks into allegations of corruption whilst he was head of the South African Revenue Service. The investigation was criticised on legal grounds{{cite web | url=http://www.groundup.org.za/article/why-hawks-dont-have-case-against-gordhan/ | title=Why the Hawks don't have a case against Gordhan | publisher=Ground Up | date=25 August 2016 | accessdate=29 August 2016 | author=Karim, Safura Abdool}} and for being politically motivated by a number of organisations and individuals including the South African Communist Party.{{cite web | url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/stop-harassing-gordhan-says-sacp-2061844 | title=Stop harassing Gordhan, says SACP | publisher=African News Agency | date=28 August 2016 | accessdate=29 August 2016}} Gordhan stated that the Gupta family was behind the charges. The Gupta family denied being involved in any effort to remove Gordhan from office,{{Cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/guptas-quit-sa-businesses-2061743|title=Guptas quit SA businesses|date=28 August 2016|website=|publisher=The Sunday Independent|access-date=28 August 2016|author1=Siyabonga Mkhwanazi|author2=Lungani Zulu}} however, in 2017, much of Gupta auditor [[KPMG]]’s senior leadership in South Africa resigned, and a report, issued by KPMG in 2015, accusing Gordhan of improprieties was withdrawn, after an internal investigation found that the work done by KPMG for Gupta family fell “considerably short” of the firm’s standards, and amid a rising political and public backlash.{{cite news|last1=Brock|first1=Joe|title=KPMG South Africa senior leaders resign over Gupta scandal|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/kpmg-south-africa-gupta-scandal-senior-leaders-resign-auditor-government-contracts-trevor-hoole-a7948286.html|accessdate=22 September 2017|work=The Independent|date=15 Sep 2017}} ==== Power plants ==== The Gupta family was implicated in the alleged improper awarding of a contract to install a new [[Boiler (power generation)|boiler]] at the [[Duvha Power Station]] to [[Dongfang Electric]] after the Gupta connected advisory firm Trillian gave the Dongfang bid the go ahead. [[General Electric]] filed court papers stating that Dongfang was given the contract through a rigged tendering process by Eskom even though the Dongfang bid was R1 billion (US$76 million) more than the General Electric bid.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/energy/2017-04-26-ge-claims-eskom-favoured-trillion-bid/|title=GE claims Eskom favoured Chinese firm's bid, with backing of Trillian|last=STEPHAN HOFSTATTER AND CAROL PATON|first=|date=26 April 2017|work=Business Day|access-date=2017-04-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170427004129/https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/energy/2017-04-26-ge-claims-eskom-favoured-trillion-bid/|archive-date=2017-04-27|dead-url=yes|language=en-US}} === Railways === The Gupta family along with Duduzane Zuma have been implicated in an attempt to improperly influence the awarding of a R51 billion (roughly equivalent to US$6 billion in 2012) contract to deliver 600 trains to South Africa on behalf of the [[CSR Corporation Limited|China South Rail]] company. In 2012 the former head of the South African [[Passenger Rail Agency of South Africa|Passenger Rail Agency]] (Prasa), Lucky Montana, wrote a letter detailing an attempt by the Guptas and Zuma to pressure then South African minister of transport, [[Ben Martins]], and Montana, Prasa’s then CEO, to favour China South Rail. The letter became public in June 2016 when Montana sent a copy to the [[amaBhungane Centre for Investigative Journalism]].{{Cite web|url=http://amabhungane.co.za/article/2016-06-19-guptas-r51bn-train-grab|title=amaBhungane - Guptas' R51bn train grab|website=amabhungane.co.za|access-date=2016-07-16}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/stnews/investigations/2016/06/19/The-Guptas-R51bn-train-grab|title=The Guptas' R51bn train grab|last=SOLE|first=STEFAANS BRÜMMER and SAM|website=Sunday Times|access-date=2016-07-16}} ==== SAP kickback allegations==== {{see also|SAP SE#South African allegations}} In July 2017, [[SAP SE|SAP]] was accused of having paid CAD House, a Gupta-controlled company, R100 million in order to secure a [[Transnet]] deal in 2015. SAP denied the allegations, claiming that the money was paid as "an extension of the sales force", despite CAD House having no prior SAP experience.{{Cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/guptaleaks-software-giant-paid-gupta-front-r100m-kickbacks-for-state-business-20170711|title=#GuptaLeaks: Software giant paid Gupta front R100m 'kickbacks' for state business|work=News24|access-date=2017-07-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://amabhungane.co.za/article/2017-07-11-guptaleaks-software-giant-sap-paid-gupta-front-r100m-kickbacks-for-state-business|title=amaBhungane - #GuptaLeaks: Software giant SAP paid Gupta front R100m "kickbacks" for state business|website=amabhungane.co.za|language=en|access-date=2017-07-11}} As a consequence of the allegations, SAP suspended some managers, and launched an investigation{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d8d693c0-67d8-11e7-8526-7b38dcaef614|title=Germany’s SAP to investigate South Africa kickback allegations|last=|first=|date=|website=Financial Times|access-date=}} appointing an acting managing director for Africa while the investigation continued.{{Cite news|url=http://www.itweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=163367|title=SAP names Kuehnemann as acting MD|last=Writer|first=Staff|work=ITWeb Technology News|access-date=2017-07-17}} === Armaments === VR Laser Services, in which the Guptas and Duduzane Zuma, President Zuma's son, own a 25% stake, entered into a partnership with the state owned aerospace and defence company [[Denel]] to establish Denel Asia, based in Hong Kong. The official opposition, [[Democratic Alliance (South Africa)|Democratic Alliance]] have alleged that the establishment of the joint venture is illegal as certain provisions of the Public Finance Management Act have not been complied with. The [[Minister of Public Enterprises]], [[Lynne Brown]], confirmed that the Asian marketing arm of Denel was not in compliance with various legal provisions.{{cite news|url=http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=42373:denel-asia-could-be-unlawful&catid=7:Industry&Itemid=116 |title=Denel Asia could be unlawful |publisher=defenceWeb |date=2016-02-17 |accessdate=2016-03-03}}{{cite news|author=Carol Paton |url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/2016/02/16/denel-and-gupta-venture-illegal |title=Denel and Gupta venture ‘illegal’ | National |publisher=BDlive |date=2016-02-16 |accessdate=2016-03-03}} ===Media=== The international news broadcaster [[Al Jazeera English]] has alleged that Zuma's close relationship with the Guptas has "translated into friendly coverage in the outlets they own,"{{cite AV media | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FyM0jjlmLrI | title=Jacob Zuma's friends and foes in South Africa's media - The Listening Post (Feature) | publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]: English | date=20 March 2016 | medium=Video | location=0:40}} specifically ANN7 and the New Age. ==== Economic Freedom Fighters criticism ==== On 4 February 2016 [[Julius Malema]] of the [[Economic Freedom Fighters]] (EFF) announced that members of the press from Gupta owned media companies, ANN7 and The New Age, would no longer be welcome at future EFF media announcements. The EFF alleged that this was because of their role as being part of a "propaganda machinery" of a "corrupt cartel". He stated that the EFF "cannot guarantee the safety of those who are working in those studios and printing factories of the New Age and ANN7."{{cite web | url=http://citizen.co.za/977891/juju-outburst-reviled/ | title=Juju outburst reviled | publisher=[[The Citizen (South Africa)|The Citizen]] | date=5 February 2016 | accessdate=9 February 2016 |author1=Yadhana Jadoo |author2=Steven Tau |author3=Travis Carlyle }}{{cite web | url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-02-04-malema-refuses-to-settle-with-crook-zuma | title=Malema refuses 'crook' Zuma's offer, calls for Guptas to leave SA | publisher=[[Mail and Guardian]] | date=4 February 2016 | accessdate=11 February 2016 | author=Quintal, Genevieve}} The EFF criticised the "New Age Breakfasts", a series of breakfast events organised by The New Age with and often paid for by government departments, as well as accused the paper of receiving preferential treatment in receiving advertising contracts from government.{{cite web | url=http://businesstech.co.za/news/government/111769/eff-slams-zuma-and-gupta-criminal-enterprises/ | title=EFF slams Zuma and Gupta "criminal enterprises" | publisher=Business Tech | date=8 February 2016 | accessdate=9 February 2016}} A spokesperson for the African National Congress defended the Gupta family, stressing their history of investment in South Africa.{{cite video |people= Jesse Duarte |date=10 February 2016 |title= Jesse Duarte on President Zuma's relationship with the Guptas |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z7Hh1Y51m-o |medium= |language= |publisher= |location= |accessdate=18 February 2016 |time= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }} A few days later the EFF released a list of 25 reasons why they are against the family, again accusing them of receiving preferential treatment in business dealings with government as well as government preference and collusion with Gupta owned media interests.{{cite web | url=http://www.politicsweb.co.za/politics/25-reasons-why-the-guptas-must-leave-sa--eff | title=25 reasons why the Guptas must leave SA – EFF | publisher=Economic Freedom Fighters | date=10 February 2016 | accessdate=11 February 2016 | author=Mbuyiseni Quintin Ndlozi}} The EFF's perceived threats towards ANN7 and New Age employees caused a number of other media commentators and publications to criticise Malema's remarks as threatening [[media independence]] and advocating violence towards the media and a particularly strong rebuke from the New Age and ANN7.{{cite web | url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/the-new-age-ann7-editor-slams-malemas-utterances-and-threats-20160204 | title=The New Age, ANN7 editor slams Malema's 'utterances and threats' | publisher=[[News24]] | date=4 February 2016 | accessdate=9 February 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-02-04-editorial-nothing-justifies-threats-against-journalists/ | title=Editorial: Nothing justifies threats against journalists | publisher=[[Daily Maverick]] | date=4 February 2016 | accessdate=9 February 2016}} An anti-gag order disallowing the EFF from banning The New Age and ANN7 from EFF media briefings was issued by the High Court following Malema's remarks.{{cite web | url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/why-judge-granted-gupta-gag-order-1984052 | title=Why judge granted Gupta gag order | publisher=[[Pretoria News]] | date=13 February 2016 | accessdate=13 February 2016 | author=Zelda Venter}} The court also upheld the applicants’ rights and those of the Gupta family as South African citizens to remain in South Africa and carry out business operations.{{cite news |author= |title=Gupta family win court interdict against EFF‚ Julius Malema |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2016/02/09/Gupta-family-win-court-interdict-against-EFF%E2%80%9A-Julius-Malema |newspaper=Business Day Live |location= |date=9 February 2016 |access-date=18 February 2016}} The judge presiding over the case concluded that Malema’s statement was a “threat of violence” and said the Guptas and their employees “have a constitutionally protected right not to be threatened with violence”.{{cite news |author= |title=EFF's Gupta comments are actual threats - judge |url= http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/stnews/2016/02/12/EFFs-Gupta-comments-are-actual-threats---judge |newspaper=Business Day Live |location= |date=9 February 2016 |access-date=18 February 2016}} ==== Sekunjalo Investments dispute ==== In November 2012, the Gupta family, through Oakbay, were granted an option to buy 50% of the shares of Independent News and Media South Africa, one of the largest newspaper operations in South Africa, after the company had been bought out by [[Sekunjalo Investments]] who was negotiating the purchase of the group from the Irish owned [[Independent News & Media|Independent News and Media]]. After the successful purchase of the group by Sekunjalo in February 2013 Oakbay sought to exercise its share purchase options. This led to disagreements between Oakbay and Sekunjalo about the true value and cost of the options and so they could not settle on an agreement as to how much Oakbay should pay for the shares. Ten percent of buyout by Sekunjalo was also funded by the South African Government Employees Pension Fund who had never agreed to Oakbay having the options and, when asked in early 2016, rejected Oakbay's request to exercise the option to buy 50% of the now Sekunjalo owned newspaper publishing company. This led to Oakbay taking Sekunjalo to court.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-06-09-fear-and-loathing-first-look-at-guptas-attempt-to-bite-a-chunk-of-iqbal-survs-stake-in-independent-media/#.V1qxkZF96hc|title=Fear and loathing: First look at Guptas’ attempt to bite a chunk of Iqbal Survé’s stake in Independent Media {{!}} Daily Maverick|website=www.dailymaverick.co.za|access-date=2016-06-10}} ====Public relations efforts and the Bell Pottinger controversy==== {{see also|Bell Pottinger}} {{quote box | quote = "[T]he NEC expressed its utmost disgust at the arrogance, disrespect and reckless journalism displayed by the New Age Newspaper (18, 19 March 2016), ANN7 News Channel (16–18 March 2016) and representatives of the Gupta-family. They have characterized the ANC as a group of factions for and against President Zuma."
- [[Gwede Mantashe]], ANC secretary general{{cite web | url=http://www.anc.org.za/show.php?id=11965 | title=ANC statement following the National Executive Committee Meeting held 18-20 March 2016 | publisher=African National Congress | date=20 March 2016 | accessdate=26 March 2016 | author=Mantashe, Gwede | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160407125959/http://www.anc.org.za/show.php?id=11965 | archivedate=7 April 2016 | df= }} | align = right | width = 25% }} To deal with mounting public criticism the Gupta family hired the public relations firm [[Bell Pottinger]].{{cite web | url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/2016/03/18/guptas-enlist-top-uk-spin-doctors | title=Guptas enlist top UK spin doctors | publisher=Business Day | date=18 March 2016 | accessdate=24 March 2016 | author=Mkokeli, Sam}} In late February 2016 several internet-based sources were altered to be favourable to the Guptas. These included activities in Wikipedia, chat rooms, blogs and on news articles related to the Gupta family.{{cite web | url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-03-17-gupta-image-gets-cleaned-up-online | title=Gupta image gets cleaned up online | publisher=Mail and Guardian | date=18 March 2016 | accessdate=24 March 2016 | author=De Wet, Phillip}} It is thought by the ''[[Mail and Guardian]]'' that these favourable alterations were part of a sustained media campaign to improve the family's image. After emails from servers associated with Gupta newspapers were leaked,{{cite news|last1=Areff|first1=Ahmed|title=Over 100 000 Gupta emails said to be leaked: Expect more Zuma bombshells|url=http://www.biznews.com/leadership/2017/06/01/100-000-gupta-emails-leaked-zuma/|accessdate=10 July 2017|work=BIZnews|date=June 1, 2017}} Bell Pottinger was reported to be involved in substantial editing of this Wikipedia page about the Guptas; a Bell Pottinger employee was said to have emailed much of the content to a Gupta account for it to be uploaded.{{cite news|last1=Cowan|first1=Kyle|title=Bell Pottinger’s wicked Wiki ways|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2017-07-10-bell-pottingers-wicked-wiki-ways/|accessdate=10 July 2017|work=Sunday Times (South Africa)|date=10 July 2017}} In a statement to the ''Financial Times'' on 25 November 2016, Bell Pottinger stated that their role has been “to correct misperceptions” about Oakbay. They have intended to communicate that a competitive, disruptive, job-creating narrative is what is needed to achieve transformation in South Africa.{{Cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/1290e44a-b24d-11e6-9c37-5787335499a0 |title=Zuma mixes new media and old-style tactics to fight detractors |newspaper=Financial Times |access-date=2016-12-18 |subscription=yes}} Gupta owned media outlets, ANN7 and ''The New Age'', ran stories alleging an anti-Zuma plot by a faction within the ANC was one possible source of allegations against the Gupta family.{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-03-22-trainspotter-how-the-new-age-ann7-and-the-guptas-have-spun-state-capture/#.VvQnh_l96Uk | title=Trainspotter: How The New Age, ANN7 and the Guptas have spun state capture | publisher=Daily Maverick | date=22 March 2016 | accessdate=26 March 2016 | author=Poplak, Richard}}{{cite web | url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/Politics/gupta-owned-media-coverage-reckless-journalism-anc-20160320 | title=Gupta-owned media coverage 'reckless journalism' - ANC | publisher=News24 | date=20 March 2016 | accessdate=26 March 2016 | author=Quintal, Genevieve}} Following the ANC's national executive council meeting in March 2016 the ANC's secretary general issued a statement criticising the coverage of the event by Gupta family owned media. In response ANN7 and ''The New Age'' agreed to publish an official apology to the ANC.{{cite web | url=http://www.techcentral.co.za/gupta-media-to-say-sorry-to-anc/64064/ | title=Gupta media to say sorry to ANC | publisher=Tech Central | date=23 March 2016 | accessdate=26 March 2016}} Bell Pottinger announced they had dropped the Gupta family as clients{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/213309f3-ce30-31fb-abc0-c940b0b42ddd|title=Bell Pottinger drops Gupta-owned client amid South Africa tensions|last=Cotterill|first=Joseph|date=12 April 2017|website=www.ft.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-04-13}} on 12 April 2017 . This followed a ''[[The Sunday Times (South Africa)|Sunday Times]]''{{Cite web|url=http://www.farmingportal.co.za/index.php/actualities/item/9966-white-monopoly-capital-chosen-distraction-in-pr-strategy-to-clear-guptas|title='White monopoly capital' chosen distraction in PR strategy to clear Guptas|last=SHOBA|first=SABELO SKITI and SIBONGAKONKE|website=Sunday Times|access-date=2017-07-24}} article that claimed that the Gupta family and President Zuma worked with the firm to incite racial tensions using [[Social bot|bots]] and [[Sockpuppet (Internet)|sockpuppets]] on [[social media]] in an effort to manipulate public opinion. Leaked emails allegedly from the Guptas suggested that the family planned to deal with negative publicity by buying newspapers critical of the family such as ''Mail & Guardian''.{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/stnews/2017/06/05/Project-M-the-Gupta-plan-to-buy-the-Mail-Guardian|title=Project M - the Gupta plan to buy the Mail & Guardian|last=Cowan|first=Kyle|date=5 June 2017|website=Sunday Times|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170605165447/http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/stnews/2017/06/05/Project-M-the-Gupta-plan-to-buy-the-Mail-Guardian|archive-date=2017-06-05|dead-url=yes|access-date=2017-06-07}} Bell Pottinger went into administration (bankruptcy) in September 2017, as a consequence of the scandal resulting from activities undertaken by the firm on behalf of the Guptas, particularly its role in inflaming racial tension in South Africa.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2017/sep/05/bell-pottingersouth-africa-pr-firm |title=Deal that undid Bell Pottinger: inside story of the South Africa scandal |first=Andrew |last=Cave |date=5 September 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=19 February 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/5309bb7a-97d8-11e7-b83c-9588e51488a0 |title=Bell Pottinger’s UK arm goes into administration |newspaper=Financial Times |accessdate=19 February 2018 |subscription=yes}} ===== Fake news ===== Media interests owned by Gupta were blamed by other South African media organisations and civil society organisations for running [[fake news]] campaigns against a number of individuals and groups judged hostile to Gupta interests. Targets included ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', ''Sunday Times,'' [[Radio 702]], and ''[[City Press (South Africa)|City Press]]'' in addition to individuals such as Finance Minister [[Pravin Gordhan]] who was seen as blocking Gupta attempts at [[state capture]].{{Cite news|url=http://citizen.co.za/opinion/opinion-columns/1407075/fake-news-threatening-sas-stability/|title=Fake news that leaves a whiff of Gupta|last=Williams|first=Martin|newspaper=The Citizen|language=en|access-date=2017-01-29}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2017/01/23/fake-news-its-not-as-straight-up-as-it-seems/|title=Fake News -- 'It's shifting the political narrative'|last=Ngoepe|first=Karabo|date=23 January 2017|website=Huffington Post South Africa|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|access-date=2017-01-29}} Attacks against Gordhan focused on accusations of him promoting state capture for "white monopoly capital".{{Cite news|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2017-01-27-00-hidden-hand-drives-social-media-smears|title=Hidden hand drives social media smears|last=Roux|first=Jean le|date=27 January 2017|work=|newspaper=[[Mail and Guardian]]|language=en|access-date=2017-01-29|via=}} === Corporate response === Due to the controversial nature of the family's relationship with Jacob Zuma numerous South African and international banking and auditing firms decided to end their business dealings with Gupta-owned firms in early April 2016. The auditing firm [[KPMG]], the brokerage [[Sasfin Bank]], and [[Barclays]] Africa’s [[Absa Group Limited|Absa]] bank as well as [[First National Bank (South Africa)|First National Bank]] all announced that they would no longer be dealing with the Gupta-owned Oakbay Investments, the holding company for the family's investments.{{cite web | url=http://www.iol.co.za/business/companies/bankers-auditors-drop-gupta-linked-firms-2006167 | title=Bankers, auditors drop Gupta-linked firms | publisher=IOL news | date=7 April 2016 | accessdate=7 April 2016 |author1=Franz Wild |author2=Renee Bonorchis }}{{cite web | url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/businesstimes/2016/04/04/KPMG-Sasfin-cut-links-with-Gupta-firm | title=KPMG, Sasfin cut links with Gupta firm | publisher=[[Sunday Times (South Africa)|Sunday Times]] | date=4 April 2016 | accessdate=7 April 2016 | author=Cropley, Ed & Motsoeneng, Tisetso}}{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2016-04-07-state-capture-banking-and-business-screws-on-the-guptas-tighten-considerably/#.VwbDN_l96Uk | title=State Capture: Banking and business screws on the Guptas tighten considerably | publisher=[[Daily Maverick]] | date=7 April 2016 | accessdate=7 April 2016 | author=Thamm, Marianne}} Johan van Dyk at the South African financial forensics firm Censeo stated that companies were disassociating with the family due to concerns that an association with the family could cost them customers. In response the Gupta-owned Oakbay alleged that this is "clear proof that the recent allegations against the company and the wider Gupta family are all part of a carefully orchestrated political campaign". Oakbay executives publicly repeated the accusation and went on to accuse South African businessman [[Johann Rupert|Johan Rupert]] of being involved in a conspiracy against them. Oakbay stated that Rupert, through the Rupert-owned Remgro investment company, had interests in the country's financial institutions and that this allowed him to influence banks so that they would stop doing business with Oakbay. Although Remgro had a 3.3% share ownership in FirstRand it did not have any investments or ownership in any of the other financial institutions Oakbay accused it of having.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/national/2016/05/06/exclusive-oakbay-conspiracy-theory-claims-sas-banks-are-controlled-by-ruperts|title=EXCLUSIVE: Oakbay ‘conspiracy theory’ claims SA’s banks are controlled by Ruperts|website=Business Day Live|access-date=2016-05-07}} On 8 April 2016, Duduzane Zuma, Atul Gupta, and Varun Gupta announced that they would be stepping down from their director positions at Oakbay Resources and Energy in response to mounting pressure.{{cite web|url=http://www.bdlive.co.za/business/mining/2016/04/08/gupta-brothers-and-zumas-son-resign-as-directors-of-oakbay|title=Gupta brothers and Zuma’s son resign as directors of Oakbay|date=8 April 2016|publisher=Business Day|accessdate=10 April 2016|author=Laing, Robert}} Oakbay stated that it had become nearly impossible to conduct business due to the business community's decision to discontinue doing business with the controversial firm.{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/guptas-cant-bank-on-sa-2007180|title=Guptas can’t bank on SA|date=9 April 2016|publisher=IOL news|accessdate=10 April 2016|author=Dodds, Craig}}{{cite web|url=http://businesstech.co.za/news/banking/119659/watch-gupta-company-ceo-on-cnn/|title=Watch: Gupta company CEO on CNN|date=9 April 2016|publisher=Businesstech & [[CNN]]|accessdate=10 April 2016}} A few days later, Ajay and Atul Gupta along with other members of the family were reported to have left South Africa for [[Dubai]]. Julius Malema of the EFF, claimed that president Zuma illegally took out R6 billion (US$400 million) of the Gupta's money for them from South Africa when he visited the United Arab Emirates in March 2016.{{Cite web|url=http://www.techcentral.co.za/zuma-ferried-billions-for-guptas-malema/64196/|title=Zuma ferried Gupta billions out of SA: Malema {{!}} TechCentral|website=www.techcentral.co.za|access-date=2016-05-07}} The trade union and ANC political ally [[Congress of South African Trade Unions|COSATU]] criticised the move by South African financial institutions to refuse to do business with Oakbay on the grounds that it was "political posturing" and put the jobs of thousands of South African employees of the firm at risk.{{Cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-04-11-cosatu-slams-banks-for-shunning-gupta-family-businesses|title=Cosatu slams banks for shunning Gupta family businesses|last=Agency|first=African News|website=The M&G Online|access-date=2016-05-07}} On the 20th June it was reported that the Gupta family were back in South Africa after an extended time away from the country.{{cite news|url=http://businesstech.co.za/news/government/127315/the-guptas-are-back-in-south-africa/|title=The Guptas are back in South Africa|date=20 June 2016|newspaper=BusinessTech|location=|access-date=24 June 2016|author=}} On 8 September 2016, after announcing their annual results, Nazeem Howa told Reuters that the company was intending to urge the four banks that ended their relationships with the company to reopen their accounts. Howa was also quoted as stating that a judicial commission of enquiry into the banks would be the “best way” to shed light on the reasoning behind their decision to close the accounts with Oakbay.{{cite news |author= |title='The truth will come out': Gupta-owned Oakbay backs judicial inquiry into banks |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2016-09-08-gupta-owned-oakbay-backs-judicial-inquiry-into-banks |newspaper=Mail & Guardian |location= |date=8 September 2016 |access-date=4 October 2016}} === Public response === Notable ANC members [[Ahmed Kathrada]] and [[Derek Hanekom]] called on the ANC to address public concerns relating to Zuma's relationship with the Gupta family.{{cite web|url=https://www.enca.com/south-africa/ahmed-kathrada-foundation-asks-anc-address-gupta-claims|title=Ahmed Kathrada Foundation asks ANC to address Gupta claims|date=22 March 2016|publisher=eNCA|accessdate=7 April 2016}} Prior to criticising financial institutions for refusing to do business with Oakbay the trade union COSATU called for president Zuma to distance himself from the Gupta family.{{cite web|url=http://ewn.co.za/2016/04/05/Cosatu-urges-Zuma-to-distance-himself-from-Gupta-family|title=COSATU URGES ZUMA TO DISTANCE HIMSELF FROM GUPTA FAMILY|date=6 April 2016|publisher=Eye Witness News|accessdate=10 April 2016}} Following Kathrada's death in March 2017, Zuma was not invited to his funeral at Kathradas family's request due to Zuma's controversial relationship with the Gupta family, and former president [[Kgalema Motlanthe]] read an open letter that Kathrada had published a year before his death calling on Zuma to resign.{{Cite web|url=http://www.enca.com/south-africa/kathrada-family-shuns-zuma|title=Kathrada family shuns Zuma|last=|first=|date=28 March 2017|website=www.enca.com|language=en|access-date=2017-04-18}} A [[Hacktivism|hacktivist]] group claiming to be associated with the African chapter of [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] launched a number of [[Distributed denial of service attack|Distributed Denial of Service]] attacks on websites associated with the Gupta family in mid-June 2016. Gupta owned companies targeted included the websites of Oakbay Investments, Oakbay Resources and Energy, The New Age, IT firm Sahara, and ANN7.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fin24.com/Tech/Companies/exclusive-why-anonymous-hacked-the-sabc-guptas-20160617|title=EXCLUSIVE: Why Anonymous 'hacked' the SABC, Gupta websites|website=Fin24|access-date=2016-06-19}} The South African artist [[Ayanda Mabulu]] exhibited a controversial painting criticizing president Zuma's controversial and close relationship with the Guptas. The painting portrayed president Zuma performing an act of [[anilingus]] on Atul Gupta in the cockpit of an airplane against a backdrop of the ANC flag.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/anc-slams-vulgar-zuma-gupta-painting-2044921|title=ANC slams ‘vulgar’ Zuma-Gupta painting|last=Molosankwe|first=Botho|date=13 July 2016|website=|publisher=The Star|access-date=16 July 2016}} President Zuma's relationship with the family became a campaign issue that negatively affected the ANC's performance in the [[South African municipal elections, 2016|2016 South African municipal elections]].{{cite web|url=https://www.enca.com/south-africa/gupta-family-just-caught-south-africa%25E2%2580%2599s-political-crossfire|title='Gupta family just caught in South Africa's political crossfire'|website=www.enca.com|access-date=2016-08-08}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.theafricareport.com/Southern-Africa/south-africas-city-hall-cliffhanger.html|title=South Africa's city hall cliffhanger {{!}} Southern Africa|last=Orderson|first=Crystal|date=4 August 2016|website=www.theafricareport.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-10}} Following the dismissal of Gordan as Minister of Finance in April 2017 anti-Zuma protests were held across South Africa including in front of the Gupta family estate in Johannesburg.{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2017/04/07/Protesters-chant-Zuma-must-go-outside-Gupta-compound|title=Protesters chant 'Zuma must go' outside Gupta compound|last=Digital|first=Tmg|website=Times LIVE|access-date=2017-04-07}} == Financial transactions == {{See also|Gupta family#Corporate response}} In October 2016, the South African Minister of Finance Pravin Gordhan stated in court documents that the Guptas were implicated in "suspicious transactions worth R6.8 billion".{{Cite web|url=http://ewn.co.za/2016/10/15/Reports-Gordhan-spills-the-beans-on-Gupta-R6-8-bln-suspicious-transactions|title=REPORTS: GORDHAN SPILLS THE BEANS ON GUPTAS R6.8 BLN 'SUSPICIOUS' TRANSACTIONS|last=Grootes|first=Stephen|date=16 October 2016|website=|publisher=Eye Witness News|access-date=27 October 2016}} The court documents were filed as part of a high court application explaining why the Minister of Finance could not intervene on the Gupta's behalf to require that South African banks continue to provide services to Gupta-owned companies. The documents stated that South African banks were alarmed by the financial dealings of 14 Gupta-owned businesses and discontinued services to the family to avoid possible legal implications.{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sundaytimes/stnews/2016/10/16/How-Gordhan-lifted-lid-on-dodgy-Gupta-dealings|title=How Gordhan lifted lid on dodgy Gupta dealings|last=Joubert|first=Jan-Jan|date=16 October 2016|website=|publisher=The Sunday Times|access-date=27 October 2016}} The Gupta's lawyers publicly disputed Gordhan's statement and stated that a number of errors were made including that a number of the disputed transactions regarding one of the financial dealings, the Optimum mine, occurred when the mine was not yet under the control of the family.{{cite news |author= |title=Guptas vow to clear the family name |url=https://www.techcentral.co.za/guptas-vow-to-clear-the-family-name/69305/ |newspaper=[[Reuters]] |location= |date=18 October 2016 |access-date=1 December 2016}} On 18 August 2017, the North Gauteng High Court dismissed Gordhan’s court application seeking declaratory relief from having to intervene with the banks' decisions to close the bank accounts of the Oakbay investments.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2017-08-18-gordhan-loses-court-battle-against-the-guptas/|title=Gordhan loses court battle against the Guptas|access-date=2017-08-24|language=en-US}} An investigation by the South African-based amaBhungane Centre for Investigative Journalism alleges that the Guptas benefited from a number of state contracts using their political connections through a sophisticated system of financial dealings totalling up to R144 million (US$10.6 million) in only one six-month period.{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.za/2016/12/07/a-dummys-guide-to-the-guptas-money-laundering-allegations/|title=A Dummy's Guide To The Gupta's Money-Laundering Allegations|last=HuffPost SA|first=|date=8 December 2016|website=Huffington Post South Africa|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|access-date=2017-01-29}} A report compiled by the [[South African Council of Churches]] and South African academics stated that R40 billion (equivalent to US$3 billion) was illegally smuggled out of South Africa to Dubai by the Gupta family and their associated companies between 2011/12 and 2017. The money having allegedly originated from South African [[Parastatal|parastatial]]s such as South African Airways, Eskom and Transnet.{{Cite news|url=https://www.iol.co.za/news/politics/sacp-vets-shocked-by-r40bn-smuggled-to-dubai-10284857|title=SACP, vets shocked by 'R40bn smuggled to Dubai' {{!}}|last=Ndaba|first=Baldwin|date=14 July 2017|work=The Star|access-date=2017-09-13|language=en}} The Gupta family has filed an interdict against its last remaining bank in South Africa, the [[Bank of Baroda]], to prevent it from closing their accounts at the bank.{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2017-09-08-september-21-judgment-day-for-guptas-baroda-bank-accounts/|title=Judgment day for Guptas’ Baroda bank accounts|last=Cowan|first=Kyle|date=8 September 2017|work=Sunday Times|access-date=2017-09-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908190623/https://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2017-09-08-september-21-judgment-day-for-guptas-baroda-bank-accounts/|archive-date=2017-09-08|dead-url=yes|language=en-US}} The Bank of Baroda did this after flagging 36 suspicious transactions on Gupta linked accounts over a ten-month period valued at R4.2bn and amid accusations of the bank helping the family [[Money laundering|launder money]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/financial-services/2017-09-11-how-bank-of-baroda-was-overwhelmed-by-suspicious-gupta-linked-accounts/|title=How Bank of Baroda was overwhelmed by suspicious Gupta-linked accounts|last=Marrian|first=Natasha|date=11 September 2017|work=Business Day|access-date=2017-09-14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912092635/https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/financial-services/2017-09-11-how-bank-of-baroda-was-overwhelmed-by-suspicious-gupta-linked-accounts/|archive-date=2017-09-12|dead-url=yes|language=en-US}} On 4 September 2017 the Bank of Baroda was fined R11 million (equivalent to US$837,000) by the South Africa Financial Intelligence Centre for flouting anti-corruption laws in transactions on accounts owned by the Gupta family.{{Cite news|url=https://www.moneyweb.co.za/news/companies-and-deals/fic-fines-bank-of-baroda-for-flouting-anti-corruption-laws/|title=FIC fines Bank of Baroda for flouting anti-corruption laws|date=2017-09-04|work=Moneyweb|access-date=2018-08-27|language=en-US}} By September 2017 two international and four South African banks had closed Gupta linked accounts they had held due to suspicious transactions. == Sales of business units in August 2017 == On 21 August 2017, Oakbay announced the sale of both of its media units; ANN7 (Infinity Media) and ''The New Age'' (TNA Media) to a firm named Lodidox, owned by [[Mzwanele Manyi]]. Per the company's statement, Oakbay would sell its shareholding in Infinity Media (ANN7 TV news) for R300-million and its two-thirds stake in TNA Media (''The New Age'') for R150-million.{{Cite news|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2017-08-21-oakbay-sells-the-new-age-and-ann7-to-mzwanele-manyi-for-r450-million|title=Guptas sell The New Age and ANN7 to Mzwanele Manyi for R450m|last=Reporter|first=Staff|work=The M&G Online|access-date=2017-08-24|language=en}} The sale was [[vendor finance]]d which entailed the lending of R450 million in shares to the Manyi owned Lodidox by the Gupta owned Oakbay so that the business sale could take place.{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2017-08-22-seven-useful-facts-about-mzwanele-manyis-gupta-deal/|title=Seven useful facts about Mzwanele Manyi’s Gupta deal|last=Child|first=Katharine|date=22 August 2017|work=Business Day|access-date=2017-10-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829153441/https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2017-08-22-seven-useful-facts-about-mzwanele-manyis-gupta-deal/|archive-date=2017-08-29|dead-url=yes|language=en-US}} The EFF criticised the deal by stating that it was a form of fronting to disguise continued Gupta ownership.{{Cite web|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2017-08-22-mzwanele-manyis-gupta-media-deal-is-just-a-front-says-eff/|title=Mzwanele Manyi’s Gupta media deal is just a front, says EFF|last=|first=|date=22 August 2017|website=Business Day|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829162202/https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/national/2017-08-22-mzwanele-manyis-gupta-media-deal-is-just-a-front-says-eff/|archive-date=2017-08-29|dead-url=yes|access-date=}} On 23 August 2017, Oakbay announced the sale of Tegeta Exploration and Resources business to Swiss-based Charles King SA for R2.97-billion. Oakbay stipulated that the purchaser safeguards the employment in the mines along with having a minimum of 30% of the shares allocated to a Black Empowerment Partner.{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2017-08-23-guptas-shed-mining-business-to-save-staff/|title=Tegeta: Guptas shed mining business to ‘save staff’ {{!}} Daily Maverick|website=www.dailymaverick.co.za|access-date=2017-08-24}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == *{{cite book|last1=Myburgh |first1=Pieter-Louis |title=[[The Republic of Gupta]]|year=2017|publisher=Penguin Books South Africa|isbn=9781776090891}} *{{cite book|last1=Pauw |first1=Jacques |title=[[The President's Keepers]]|year=2017|publisher=NB Publishers|isbn=9780624083030}} {{Politics of South Africa navbox}} {{Jacob Zuma}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gupta family}} [[Category:Family trees]] [[Category:Jacob Zuma|Jacob Zuma]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:South African families]] [[Category:South African businesspeople]] [[Category:2016 in South Africa]] [[Category:2013 in South Africa]]

bank stub
/* Industry level representation */
revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Ibec |motto = For Irish Business |formation = 1993 |purpose = Irish Business |location = 84/86 Baggot Street Lower, [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Edel Creely |leader_title2 = CEO |leader_name2 = Danny McCoy |website = [http://www.ibec.ie] }}
'''Ibec''' (''formerly Irish Business and Employers Confederation'') is the largest business lobby group and largest lobbying organisation in Ireland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.farmersjournal.ie/ifa-second-most-active-lobbying-organisation-on-official-register-209713|title=IFA second most active lobbying organisation on official register|website=www.farmersjournal.ie|access-date=2016-06-15}}</ref> It represents business of all sizes spanning every sector of the economy, together employing 70% of the private sector workforce in Ireland. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibec.ie/IBEC/IBEC.nsf/vPages/About_Us~about-ibec?OpenDocument|title=About Ibec {{!}} Ibec - For Irish business|website=Ibec|access-date=2016-06-15}}</ref>
The organisation works to promote business interests by [[lobbying]] and advising governments, policy makers and key stakeholders, creating networking opportunities for businesses and providing business insight.
Ibec also supports member companies with advice on industrial relations and management of employees.
The organisation employs over 240 staff, has 42 brands representing individual trade associations and operates nationally through six national offices in: Dublin (HQ), Cork, Galway, Waterford, Limerick and Donegal, and internationally through its Brussels office. Ibec is directed and managed by a board, national council, and executive director team.
==History== Formerly known as the Irish Business and Employers Confederation (IBEC), but now just the acronym "Ibec",<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://agenda.ibec.ie/18wf0qib8mc|title=New Ibec brand launched|website=agenda.ibec.ie|access-date=2016-06-15}}</ref> the organisation was formed in 1993 as a result of the merger of the [[Confederation of Irish Industry]] (CII, founded 1932) and the Federated Union of Employers (FUE, founded 1942).
Following the [[Post-2008 Irish economic downturn|2008 Irish economic downturn]], Ibec was one of the most prominent and positive voices in the public realm on how industry could lead the recovery.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/4b6ea768-cc9c-11df-a6c7-00144feab49a.html#axzz4AVr3SFTE|title=Ireland will recover quickly from bank crisis|last=McCoy|first=Danny|date=2010-09-30|newspaper=Financial Times|issn=0307-1766|access-date=2016-06-15}}</ref>
== Structure == The CEO of Ibec is Danny McCoy who assumed the role in June 2009.
The organisation is arranged into five divisions: Policy and Public Affairs; Employer Relations; Commercial and Operations.
Ibec’s policies and strategic priorities are set by its board and national council which are implemented by Ibec’s executive director team.
'''National council'''
Ibec's central and final decision-making authority is the 70 member national council and signs-off key Ibec policy positions. It provides a forum for the exchange of views between the constituent members and groupings of Ibec on relevant policy, sectoral and organisational issues.
'''Board'''
The Ibec board is responsible for Ibec’s corporate governance and strategic direction. It is chaired by Ibec President, Edel Creely, MD, Trilogy Technologies]].
Ibec board {| class="wikitable" |'''Board member''' |'''Position''' |'''Organisation''' |- |Edel Creely (President) |MD |Trilogy Technologies |- |Leo Crawford |Group CE |[[BWG Foods|BWG Group]] |- |Gerry Collins |VP Strategy |[[Johnson & Johnson|J&J Supply Chain]] |- |Larry Murrin |CEO |Dawn Farm Foods |- |John Kennedy |President |[[Diageo]] Europe, Russia and Turkey |- |Danny McCoy |CEO |Ibec |- |Liam O'Donoghue |COO |Ibec |- |Paraic Curtis |Vice President, MedSurg Europe |[[Boston Scientific|Boston Scientific Ltd]] |- |Kevin Toland |CEO |[[Dublin Airport Authority]] |- |Brian MacCraith |President |[[Dublin City University|DCU]] |- |Siobhan Talbot |Group MD |[[Glanbia|Glanbia Plc]] |- |Patrick Manley |CEO General Insurance, EMEA |[[Zurich Insurance Group|Zurich Insurance plc]] |- |Alastair Blair |Country Managing Director |[[Accenture]] Accenture Ireland |- |Anne Heraty CEO CPL Resources |- |Frank Gleeson |Region Managing Director and COO |[[Aramark|Aramark Northern Europe]] |- |Cathriona Hallahan |Managing Director |[[Microsoft|Microsoft Ltd.]] |- |Tony Smurfit |Chief Executive Officer |[[Smurfit Kappa]] |} '''Executive director team'''
The executive director team, led by Ibec CEO Danny McCoy is responsible for the development and implementation of Ibec's strategic implementation plan.
Executive director team: {| class="wikitable" |'''Name''' |'''Position''' |- |Danny McCoy |CEO |- |Liam O'Donoghue |Deputy CEO/COO |- |Fergal O'Brien |Director of Policy and Public Affairs |- |Maeve McElwee |Director of Employer Relations |- |Martin Wells |Commercial Director |}
== Policy == Ibec develops its lobbying strategy through its 17-member policy team and 9 policy committees which are chaired and populated by members of Ibec. Committees meet on a quarterly basis, addressing the challenges and issues facing business and employers.
Ibec policy committees: * Digital Economy Policy Committee * Innovation, Science and Technology Committee * European Affairs and Trade Policy Committee * Labour Market and Skills Council * Economic and Taxation Committee * Diversity Forum * Occupational Health and Safety Committee * Transport Council * Environment Policy Committee
== Industry level representation == Ibec has over 40 business associations within the organisation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibec.ie/IBEC/IBEC.nsf/vPages/About_Us~ibec-business-sectors?OpenDocument|title=Ibec business sectors {{!}} Ibec - For Irish business|website=Ibec|access-date=2016-06-15}}</ref> Each association is supported by a professional team of industry experts.
Ibec’s main sectors are: * [[Alcohol Beverage Federation of Ireland]] (ABFI) * Audio-visual Federation (AVF) * BioPharmaChem Ireland (BPCI) * Building Materials Federation (BMF) * Cement Manufactures Ireland(CMI) * Consumer Electronics (CEDA) * Federation of Aerospace Engineering industries (FAEI) * Federation of Irish Renderers (FIR) affiliate * Financial Services Ireland (FSI) * Food and Drink Industry Ireland (FDII) * Forestry (IFFPA) * ICT Ireland * Irish Association of Pigmeat Processors (IAPM) * Irish Beer Association (IBA) * Irish Biscuits and Chocolate Association (IBCA) * Irish Bread Bakers Association (IBBA) * Irish Cellular Industry Association (ICIA) * Irish Cider Association * Irish Coffee Association (ICA) * Irish Cold Storage Federation (ICSF) * Irish Contract Cleaners Association (ICCA) * Irish Cosmetics Detergents Association (ICDA) * Irish Decorative Surfaces Association (IDSCA) * Irish Diary Industries Association (IDIA) * Irish Engineering Enterprises Federation (IEEF) * Irish Manufacturers Association (IMA) * Irish Medical Devices Association (IMDA) * Irish Mining and Engineering Group (IMEG) * Irish Ports Association (IPA) * Irish Software Association (ISA) * Irish Spirits Association * Irish Whiskey Association * Irish Wine Association. * Meat Industry Ireland (MII) * Mobile Operators messaging forum (MOM) * Petfood Association of Ireland (PFAI) * Plastics Ireland * Prepared Consumer Foods (PCF) Council * Property Industry Ireland (PII) * Retail Ireland * Small Firms Association (SFA) * Telecommunications Internet Federation (TIF) * White Goods Association (WGA)
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.ibec.ie IBEC homepage]
{{Confederation of European Business}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Irish Business And Employers Confederation}} [[Category:Economy of the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Employers' organizations]] [[Category:Business organisations based in the Republic of Ireland]]
Also, see IBEC: Innovative Building Energy Controls
